Put the rally history aside storied as
it may be
and the Subaru WRX STI's mix of performance hardware

and economy car versatility seems bizarre
but hugely intriguing.

Why not have a sports car you can drive
every day

and everywhere? For 2015 we have the next
generation STI

which has a significantly stiffer
chassis and many other improvements.

But it isn't entirely all-new the two
and a half liter turbo flat for that

power the STI since 2008 remains largely
unchanged.

Still channeling 305 horsepower and 290
pound feet of torque

to all four wheels through a six-speed
manual and we're most interested in

finding out whether the new STI still
has it.
The plan goes as follows: we'll get our first taste of the STI at the press launch at

Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca then we'll
run it through the Ignition test treatment
and then we'll take it along
one of our favorite curvy roads.
Now the STI on track I've had a bit of time to warm up in it
and my initial impressions are pretty
nice.

This is the car that its really easy to
get to speed where you feel like you can reach its limits
really quickly.
It has a rather forgiving
chassis balance
and a tendency to understeer. Once you turn the wheel the car feels like it
wants to turn quickly with it.
That's kind of an alien thing in Subaru

but I really like it. The car doesn't
flop around like I remember the oldest

STI's doing. Also our car has a short
shift kit
and its really nice to know the gears. I like

the interaction between the clutch pedal and
the gas. It's not difficult to get heel-toe

downshifts right the car makes it pretty
easy
and the stability as we go over 1 here

in the fifth gear at 100 miles an hour
is pretty good.

This car has a a break assisted torque
vectoring system or as we're calling it
now break vectoring.
And it's off

when you have the stability control
completely off which we do now
this car on the track has a lot of pads in it because a lot of journalists were cycling

through this car they didn't want to burn the
pads off but I'm curious about how the

torque vectoring system is gonna wear a
pair of street pads.

That's something we'll have to find out
again I'm impressed with the way the car
comes into a corner

how fast it can get in and the chassis
balance mid corners really nice too

because the way you can set it up. Turn
in, bounce,

that's the best corner on the track as we
go to the cork screw.

The sound is very good too and it
matches the way this car builds
power high in the RPM range.

We're catching up to our fellow
journalists here
high level of grips I

feel like I can push this engine mid-corner
way more than
I feel like I should be able to. I have a lot of confidence driving this car fast.
And that's cool in a
track environment as we

give him some room. As we give the
driver
in front of us some room let's reflect. So

let's talk about what's underneath the
sheet metal because on the face of it
this doesn't

seem too different than a WRS. Now the front
and rear suspension
is much stiffer
has stiffer everything basically and

there's all kind of percentages they're
throwing at this card
the make it sound stiffer. The gist of it is I
love it stiffer.
Overall this STI is pretty fun
first impressions again are very very good
surprising almost. I was not expecting
this car
to be this fun frankly.

Despite the unchanged power and similar
weight this

STI handily out accelerated last year's
car although we don't recommend the red

light clutch dubs it took to get that
number.

Short gearing requires a shift to third to
reach 60
which the STI hits in 4.6 seconds.
Thats nearly a second faster than the new WRX.
The STI maintains that gap to the quarter mile
reaching it in 13.1 seconds at 104.4 miles an hour.
That's also 0.7 seconds faster than last year's
STI. Peak stopping distance improved too

the Dunlop Sportmax tires and Brembo
braking system

comprised of 13 inch rotors with four-piston
calipers front

and 12.4 inch rotors with dual
piston calipers rear
required 108 feet to stop from 60 MPH.
The most telling
benefit of the stiffer chassis appeared on the figure 8 where the 2015 STI
dropped its lap time by a large
half-second margin.
At 24.9 seconds

it's 0.4 seconds faster than the
new WRX.

Average lateral acceleration increased
0.97 G.
Now we have the STI in what would seem to be more of its natural environment.
As good as it handled on the track as fun as it was to drive
the road is a true test of how fun these
fast Subarus can be.
You can just palm down this. These cars are great
on bumpy and uneven roads that you just wanna go fast through

and don't worry about it the car will go
all over the place and bump around
just keep the steering straight and it's fine.
Steering feel is quite nice.
You still have hydraulic assist while the WRX is an electric assist.
And like the previous STI's you can hear the
hydraulic fluid

going around as you dial in some
steering input.

But overall the waiting is nice, the feedback
is nice

and the response I'm impressed with how
quickly
it corresponds when you dial in steering input.
This I like the sound a bit too.
They're piping in with this 2.5 liter they pipe in

an induction sound you can
actually hear some turbocharger
whooshing and sneezing as well and it's pretty cool at about 3500 to 4000 rpm
that's when it
starts getting in the meet of it it sounds like.

Now disappointments. I'm disappointed in
the fact that

the 2.5 liter turbo is just a
carryover engine

now that doesn't mean it's a bad engine
it's just been around for a long time
with the same horsepower and torque figures.
They've done some changes but it still feels very much like last year's STI
right now though I'm having a lot of fun.

There's a lot of confidence in this chassis a
lot of confidence in this car.

And it has an ease and accessibility with
driving it.

This car doesn't scare you there's no
worries here

in fact when you're bombing down a mountain
road that make you haven't been on
before it's a
nice thing.

As is, the STI makes no effort to hide
its intent

you may think it's a responsible car it
has four doors after all and
all-wheel-drive

but it's not. You aren't fooling anyone
just look at it

look at that wing look at those gold
wheels everyone knows the real reason

you just wanna go fast. Now Subaru's
received no shortage of criticism on the
design of the new STI.

It's rightfully earned too especially
when you put the finished product next to
the WRX concept from a few years ago.

On the other hand Subaru's never really been
in the business of designing
particularly beautiful cars

so perhaps we're expecting too much. Now
the WRX and STI are getting a lot of
flack for not looking great
and, you know, probably deserve it.
Because let's face it they aren't attractive cars but
this is a bizarrely versatile,
extremely unique car and it

retains those elements those things I like
so much about the last generation STI
so why STI?

Because the drivetrain. While the WRX
makes do with just a viscous center disc
at a nominal 50/50 torque split

the STI has an electronically controlled
and adjustable center diff

with a 41-59 split ann locking
differentials on both axles.

Where the WRX begins to falter the STI
gives the driver just that much more
control.

Combined it simply makes for a faster
and better handling car.

Graceful it's not but the new STI is
huge fun

and it succeeds in giving its
driver both versatility and the speed we love
While we're disappointed the engine hasn't been
updated since 2008

and that you can't easily option gold
wheels and that it doesn't look that
great

we keep coming back to one simple truth:
the 2015 STI
is the best driving STI yet.

title: 2015 Subaru WRX STI: The Daily Driver Rally Car Returns! - Ignition Ep. 107
